4/10/2025 Introduction to Tribology 3 â–ª Analyze the wear behavior of SS304 stainless steel and LM6/ALSi10Mg using a ball-on-disk tribometer setup with a stationary AISI 52100 bearing steel ball as the counter face material. â–ª Investigate the effect of controlled normal loads (1N, 3N, and 5N) on the wear performance of these materials. Objectives of the Study â–ª Investigate critical performance indicators such as: â–ª Specific wear rate â–ª Coefficient of friction â–ª Predominant wear mechanisms â–ª Derive insights into the tribological suitability of each material under defined operating conditions.

4/10/2025 Introduction to Tribology 30 â–ª This study evaluated the wear behavior of aluminum and SS304 stainless steel against AISI 52100 bearing steel. â–ª Tests were performed under 1N, 3N, and 5N normal loads using a ball-on-disk tribometer. â–ª Optical profilometry provided precise analysis of wear track depth, width, and cross- sectional area. â–ª Specific wear rates and wear mechanisms were compared across materials and load levels. Summary and Conclusion

4/10/2025 Introduction to Tribology 31 LM6 â–ª Decreasing trend attributed to formation of tribolayer under higher loads â–ª High coefficient of friction (~0.93) due to: â–ª Soft material nature â–ª Strong adhesion with counter face â–ª Significant plowing action SS304 Stainless Steel â–ª Coefficient of friction is lower than aluminum (~0.58â€“0.67) â–ª Wear features indicate more controlled surface degradation Conclusion Continuedâ€¦..

Tribological Insights: Load-Dependent Wear Behavior 4/10/2025 Introduction to Tribology 32 LM6 Wear Behavior: â–ª Higher wear under low load â–ª Improved resistance at higher loads â–ª Likely due to load-induced protective layers SS304 Stainless Steel Wear Behavior: â–ª Superior wear resistance at low loads â–ª Gradual deterioration as load increases

General Outlook and Future Scope 4/10/2025 Introduction to Tribology 33 â–ª Perform long-duration wear tests to evaluate the stability of the tribo layer at high loads. â–ª Study wear behavior under high temperatures and corrosive environments for real- world relevance. â–ª Extend the load range beyond 5N to examine extreme wear scenarios. â–ª Test different sliding speeds to understand how velocity influences wear mechanisms. â–ª Use SEM to characterize the tribolayerâ€™s composition, thickness, and structure. â–ª Create a computational model to simulate tribolayer formation and predict wear behavior.

Their collective expertise and mentorship were instrumental in conducting this study.

4/10/2025 Introduction to Tribology 30 â–ª This study evaluated the wear behavior of aluminum and SS304 stainless steel against AISI 52100 bearing steel. â–ª Tests were performed under 1N, 3N, and 5N normal loads using a ball-on-disk tribometer. â–ª Optical profilometry provided precise analysis of wear track depth, width, and cross- sectional area. â–ª Specific wear rates and wear mechanisms were compared across materials and load levels. Summary and Conclusion

4/10/2025 Introduction to Tribology 31 LM6 â–ª Decreasing trend attributed to formation of tribolayer under higher loads â–ª High coefficient of friction (~0.93) due to: â–ª Soft material nature â–ª Strong adhesion with counter face â–ª Significant plowing action SS304 Stainless Steel â–ª Coefficient of friction is lower than aluminum (~0.58â€“0.67) â–ª Wear features indicate more controlled surface degradation Conclusion Continuedâ€¦..

Tribological Insights: Load-Dependent Wear Behavior 4/10/2025 Introduction to Tribology 32 LM6 Wear Behavior: â–ª Higher wear under low load â–ª Improved resistance at higher loads â–ª Likely due to load-induced protective layers SS304 Stainless Steel Wear Behavior: â–ª Superior wear resistance at low loads â–ª Gradual deterioration as load increases

General Outlook and Future Scope 4/10/2025 Introduction to Tribology 33 â–ª Perform long-duration wear tests to evaluate the stability of the tribo layer at high loads. â–ª Study wear behavior under high temperatures and corrosive environments for real- world relevance. â–ª Extend the load range beyond 5N to examine extreme wear scenarios. â–ª Test different sliding speeds to understand how velocity influences wear mechanisms. â–ª Use SEM to characterize the tribolayerâ€™s composition, thickness, and structure. â–ª Create a computational model to simulate tribolayer formation and predict wear behavior.
